statements.name: PROC DS2
statements.description: Specifies that the subsequent input is DS2 language statements.

arguments.name: ANSIMODE
arguments.description: specifies that nonexistent values in fixed-length character columns and DOUBLE columns are processed as ANSI SQL null values.

arguments.name: ERRORSTOP
arguments.description: specifies whether the procedure stops executing if it encounters an error.

arguments.name: NOERRORSTOP
arguments.description: specifies whether the procedure stops executing if it encounters an error.

arguments.name: LABEL
arguments.description: specifies whether to use the column label or the column name as the column heading.

arguments.name: NOLABEL
arguments.description: specifies whether to use the column label or the column name as the column heading.

arguments.name: LIBS=
arguments.description: specifies one or more librefs that have previously been assigned to a library.

arguments.name: LOGICALEXPR=
arguments.description: specifies how logical AND and OR expressions are evaluated.

arguments.name: MEMSIZE=
arguments.description: specifies a limit for the amount of memory that is used for an underlying query (such as a SELECT statement), so that allocated memory is available to support other PROC DS2 operations.

arguments.name: MSGLIMIT=
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of error, warning, and note messages that can be written to the SAS log during the execution of the DS2 program.

arguments.name: MSGORDER=
arguments.description: specifies whether DS2 writes error, warning, and note messages to the SAS log as they are produced or after the DS2 program completes.

arguments.name: NUMBER
arguments.description: specifies to include a column named Row, which is the row (observation) number of the data as the rows are retrieved.

arguments.name: REPORTLINE
arguments.description: specifies whether log line numbers are reported in DS2 program execution messages.

arguments.name: NOREPORTLINE
arguments.description: specifies whether log line numbers are reported in DS2 program execution messages.

arguments.name: SCOND=
arguments.description: specifies the level of messages that PROC DS2 displays in the SAS log for the DS2 variable declaration strict mode, which requires that every variable must be declared in the DS2 program.

arguments.name: WARNING
arguments.description: writes warning messages to the SAS log.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: no messages are written to the SAS log.

arguments.name: NOTE
arguments.description: writes notes to the SAS log.

arguments.name: ERROR
arguments.description: writes error messages to the SAS log.

arguments.name: SESSREF=
arguments.description: specifies to run the DS2 statements in a CAS session. The CAS session is identified by its session name.

arguments.name: SESSUUID=
arguments.description: specifies to run the DS2 statements in a CAS session. The CAS session is identified by its universally unique identifier (UUID).

arguments.name: STIMER
arguments.description: specifies to write a subset of system performance statistics, such as time-elapsed statistics, to the SAS log.

arguments.name: XCODE=
arguments.description: controls the behavior of the SAS session when an NLS transcoding failure occurs.

arguments.name: ERROR
arguments.description: specifies that a run-time error occurs, which causes row processing to halt. An error message is written to the SAS log. This is the default behavior.

arguments.name: WARNING
arguments.description: specifies that the incompatible character is set to a substitution character. A warning message is written to the SAS log.

arguments.name: IGNORE
arguments.description: specifies that the incompatible character is set to a substitution character. No messages are written to the SAS log.

statements.name: BY
statements.description: Controls the operation of a MERGE or SET statement in a DS2 program and sets up special grouping variables.

arguments.name: column
arguments.description: names each column by which the table is sorted. These columns are referred to as BY variables.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: specifies that the tables are sorted in descending order by the variable that is specified. DESCENDING means largest to smallest numerically, or reverse alphabetical for character variables.

statements.name: CONTINUE
statements.description: Stops processing the current DO loop iteration and resumes with the next iteration.

statements.name: DATA
statements.description: Begins a DS2 program and provides names for any output tables.

arguments.name: table
arguments.description: specifies the name of the table. table can be one of these forms. • catalog.schema.table-name • schema.table-name • catalog.table-name • table-name • caslib.table-name

arguments.name: _ROWSET_
arguments.description: specifies that the DATA statement should not create a table, but it should instead return table rows to the client application.

arguments.name: _NULL_
arguments.description: specifies that the DATA statement should not create a table or return rows to the client application.

arguments.name: table-options
arguments.description: specifies optional arguments that the DS2 program applies when it writes rows to the output table. For more information about table options, see .

statements.name: DECLARE
statements.description: Declares one or more DS2 variables or temporary arrays.
statements.help:
DECLARE      [PRIVATE] { <data-type> <variable-list> [ <having-clause> ] } ;
< data-type >::= 
	<exact-numeric-type> |      <approximate-numeric-type> | <binary-string-type> | <string-type> 
		|      <date-type> 
   
	<exact-numeric-type> ::= 
		 {INT        | BIGINT  | SMALLINT  |       TINYINT 
			 | DECIMAL  
     [(precision 
       [,scale] )] | NUMERIC  
     [(precision 
       [,scale])] } 
        
	<approximate-numeric-type> ::=
		{ DOUBLE  |        DOUBLE PRECISION  | FLOAT  | REAL        }          
	<binary-string-type>::=
		BINARY (length)       | VARBINARY (length) 
        
	<string-type>::= 
		NCHAR  
     [ (          character-length ) ]      
		| NVARCHAR  
     [ (          character-length ) ]      
		| CHAR  
     [ (          character-length ) ]       [CHARACTER SET character-set-identifier]      
		| VARCHAR  
     [ (          character-length ) ]       [CHARACTER SET character-set-identifier]          
	<date-type>::= 
		{ TIME  |        TIMESTAMP  } [ (          precision ) ] | DATE       
  
<variable-list>::= 
	{       variable 
    [ ...variable] }     
	| { variable <array-declaration>        [variable ...<array-declaration>      ] } 
		<array-declaration>::= 
			\[ <array-bound> [,  ...< array-bound>         ] \] | \[ *        \] 
          
		<array-bound>::= 
			{          [dim-lower:] 
      dim-upper} | {          [dim-lower:] {DIM         (a[,n]) }            
  
<having-clause>::= 
	HAVING       <having-option> [ ... <having-option> ] 
    
		<having-option>::= 
			LABEL          'string' |         n'string' 
     
			| FORMAT         format 
     
			| INFORMAT         format

arguments.name: INT
arguments.description: specifies an integer variable or array.

arguments.name: BIGINT
arguments.description: specifies an integer variable or array.

arguments.name: SMALLINT
arguments.description: specifies an integer variable or array.

arguments.name: TINYINT
arguments.description: specifies an integer variable or array.

arguments.name: DECIMAL
arguments.description: specifies an exact numeric variable or array.

arguments.name: precision
arguments.description: specifies the maximum total number of decimal digits that can be stored, both to the left and to the right of the decimal point

arguments.name: scale
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of decimal digits that can be stored to the right of the decimal point

arguments.name: NUMERIC
arguments.description: specifies an exact numeric variable or array.

arguments.name: precision
arguments.description: specifies the maximum total number of decimal digits that can be stored, both to the left and to the right of the decimal point

arguments.name: scale
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of decimal digits that can be stored to the right of the decimal point

arguments.name: DOUBLE
arguments.description: specifies a floating-point variable or array.

arguments.name: FLOAT
arguments.description: specifies a floating-point variable or array.

arguments.name: REAL
arguments.description: specifies a floating-point variable or array.

arguments.name: BINARY
arguments.description: specifies a binary variable or array.

arguments.name: VARBINARY
arguments.description: specifies a varying-length binary variable or array.

arguments.name: NCHAR
arguments.description: specifies a character variable or array.

arguments.name: NVARCHAR
arguments.description: specifies a character variable or array.

arguments.name: CHAR
arguments.description: specifies a character variable or array.

arguments.name: VARCHAR
arguments.description: specifies a character variable or array.

arguments.name: character-length
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of characters that the string can hold for NCHAR, NVARCHAR, CHAR, and VARCHAR data types.

arguments.name: CHARACTER
arguments.description: specifies character set encoding information for CHAR and VARCHAR data types.

arguments.name: TIME
arguments.description: specifies a time variable or array.

arguments.name: TIMESTAMP
arguments.description: specifies both a date and time variable or array.

arguments.name: precision
arguments.description: specifies the precision for a TIME or TIMESTAMP data type.

arguments.name: DATE
arguments.description: specifies a date variable or array.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: specifies the scalar variable or array name. You can specify one or more variables or arrays. However, variable can only be of the type specified in data-type. You can mix scalar and array variables of the same type.

arguments.name: and
arguments.description: specifies a positive or negative integer that defines the number and size of the array boundary for a fixed temporary array.
specifies to create a temporary array that has dynamic bounds.

arguments.name: DIM
arguments.description: specifies that the size of the upper bounds of the array is determined by the number of elements in a dimension of a previously declared array by using a DIM function call.

arguments.name: a
arguments.description: specifies the name of a previously declared array.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the dimension, in a multidimensional array, for which you want to know the number of elements.

arguments.name: LABEL
arguments.description: assigns a descriptive label to the variable or array. The label can be a CHAR literal (string) or NCHAR literal (nstring).

arguments.name: n''
arguments.description: assigns a descriptive label to the variable or array. The label can be a CHAR literal (string) or NCHAR literal (nstring).

arguments.name: FORMAT
arguments.description: Associates any valid DS2 format with the variable or array.

arguments.name: INFORMAT
arguments.description: Associates any valid SAS informat with the variable or array.

arguments.name: PRIVATE
arguments.description: specifies variables that can be accessed only from within the package.

statements.name: DECLARE PACKAGE
statements.description: Creates a package variable and optionally creates a package instance.

arguments.name: catalog
arguments.description: is an implementation of the ANSI SQL standard for an SQL catalog, which is a data container object that groups logically related schemas. The catalog is the first-level (top) grouping mechanism in a data organization hierarchy that is used along with a schema to provide a means of qualifying names. A catalog is a metadata object in a SAS Metadata Repository.

arguments.name: schema
arguments.description: is an implementation of the ANSI SQL standard for an SQL schema, which is a data container object that groups files such as tables and views and other objects supported by a data source such as stored procedures. The schema provides a grouping object that is used along with a catalog to provide a means of qualifying names.

arguments.name: package
arguments.description: is the name of the package.

arguments.name: package-variable
arguments.description: specifies whether to create a scalar package variable or an array package variable. You can specify to create multiple package variables with the DECLARE PACKAGE statement.

arguments.name: PRIVATE
arguments.description: specifies that the package variables can be accessed only from within the package.

arguments.name: scalar-package-variable
arguments.description: specifies a name that can reference an instance of the package.

arguments.name: array-package-variable\[
arguments.description: specifies a name that can reference multiple instances of the package.

arguments.name: and
arguments.description: specifies a positive or negative integer that defines the number and size of the array boundary for a fixed array package variable.

arguments.name: DIM
arguments.description: specifies that the size of the upper bound of the array package variable is determined by the number of elements in a dimension of a previously declared array package variable by using a DIM function call.
specifies to create an array package variable that has dynamic bounds.

arguments.name: table-options
arguments.description: specifies optional arguments that the DS2 program applies when it creates a package. For more information about table options, see .

arguments.name: constructor-arguments
arguments.description: specifies any constructor arguments that are passed to the constructor of the package instance.

statements.name: DECLARE THREAD
statements.description: Creates an instance of a thread.

arguments.name: catalog
arguments.description: is an implementation of the ANSI SQL standard for an SQL catalog, which is a data container object that groups logically related schemas. The catalog is the first-level (top) grouping mechanism in a data organization hierarchy that is used along with a schema to provide a means of qualifying names. A catalog is a metadata object in a SAS Metadata Repository.

arguments.name: schema
arguments.description: is an implementation of the ANSI SQL standard for an SQL schema, which is a data container object that groups files such as tables and views and other objects supported by a data source such as stored procedures. The schema provides a grouping object that is used along with a catalog to provide a means of qualifying names.

arguments.name: thread
arguments.description: is the name of the thread.

arguments.name: instance
arguments.description: specifies a name that identifies an instance of the thread.

arguments.name: argument
arguments.description: specifies arguments used with instance.

arguments.name: table-options
arguments.description: specifies optional arguments that the DS2 program applies when it creates a thread. For more information about table options, see .

statements.name: DO
statements.description: Specifies a group of statements to be executed as a unit.
statements.help:
DO  [<numeric-data-type>][index-variable =  <index-variable-clause>] [ <conditional-clause> ]
	 [,  ...[<index-variable-clause>] [ <conditional-clause> ]];  
	 ...statement-list ... 
END  [end-label] ; 
< numeric-data-type >::= 
	<exact-numeric-type> | <approximate-numeric-type>   
	<exact-numeric-type> ::=  
		 {INT  | BIGINT  | SMALLINT  | TINYINT 
			 | DECIMAL  [(precision [,scale] )] | NUMERIC   [(precision [,scale])] } 
        
	<approximate-numeric-type> ::=
		{ DOUBLE  | DOUBLE PRECISION  | FLOAT  | REAL  } 
 
<index-variable-clause>::=  
	start  [TO stop[BY increment]] 
 
<conditional-clause>::=  
	WHILE    ( expression ) | UNTIL    ( expression )

arguments.name: statement-list
arguments.description: specifies any valid DS2 statements.

arguments.name: INT
arguments.description: specifies an integer variable or array.

arguments.name: BIGINT
arguments.description: specifies an integer variable or array.

arguments.name: SMALLINT
arguments.description: specifies an integer variable or array.

arguments.name: TINYINT
arguments.description: specifies an integer variable or array.

arguments.name: DECIMAL[
arguments.description: specifies an exact numeric variable or array.

arguments.name: precision
arguments.description: specifies the maximum total number of decimal digits that can be stored, both to the left and to the right of the decimal point

arguments.name: scale
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of decimal digits that can be stored to the right of the decimal point

arguments.name: NUMERIC[
arguments.description: specifies an exact numeric variable or array.

arguments.name: precision
arguments.description: specifies the maximum total number of decimal digits that can be stored, both to the left and to the right of the decimal point

arguments.name: scale
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of decimal digits that can be stored to the right of the decimal point

arguments.name: DOUBLE
arguments.description: specifies a floating-point variable or array.

arguments.name: FLOAT
arguments.description: specifies a floating-point variable or array.

arguments.name: REAL
arguments.description: specifies a floating-point variable or array.

arguments.name: index-variable
arguments.description: names a variable that is used as an index counter for the loop.

arguments.name: end-label
arguments.description: The END statement closes the DO loop. The optional end-label argument specifies an identifier. This label, created by using the Labels statement, must match the label immediately preceding the DO statement, or an error will occur. For more information, see the .

arguments.name: < index-variable-clause >
arguments.description: specifies a numeric scalar expression or series of expressions that determines the number of times that the DO group will be executed.

arguments.name: start
arguments.description: specifies the initial value of the index variable. start can be any expression that resolves to a numeric value.

arguments.name: TO
arguments.description: specifies the ending value of the index variable. stop can be any expression that resolves to a numeric value.

arguments.name: BY
arguments.description: specifies a positive or negative value that controls the incrementing or decrementing of index-variable. increment can be any expression that resolves to a numeric value.

arguments.name: <conditional-clause>
arguments.description: specifies a clause that returns true or false.

arguments.name: WHILE
arguments.description: causes DO group statements to execute repetitively while a condition is true.

arguments.name: UNTIL
arguments.description: causes DO group statements to execute repetitively until a condition is true.

statements.name: DROP
statements.description: Excludes columns from output tables.

arguments.name: column-list
arguments.description: specifies the name of one or more columns to omit from the output tables.

arguments.name: vararray
arguments.description: specifies the name of a variable array.

statements.name: DROP PACKAGE
statements.description: Deletes a DS2 package.

arguments.name: package
arguments.description: specifies the name of the package to be deleted.

arguments.name: table-options
arguments.description: specifies optional arguments that the DS2 program applies when it deletes a package. For more information about table options, see .

statements.name: DROP THREAD
statements.description: Deletes a DS2 thread program.

arguments.name: thread
arguments.description: specifies the name of the thread to be deleted.

arguments.name: table-options
arguments.description: specifies optional arguments that the DS2 program applies when it deletes a thread. For more information about table options, see .

statements.name: DS2_OPTIONS
statements.description: Specifies or changes the default behavior of a DS2 program.

arguments.name: DIVBYZERO=
arguments.description: specifies how DS2 processes a division by zero operation.

arguments.name: LOGICALEXPR=
arguments.description: specifies how logical AND and OR expressions in the next program block are evaluated.

arguments.name: MISSING_NOTE
arguments.description: writes a note to the SAS log when an invalid function argument generates a missing value.

arguments.name: MSGLIMIT=
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of error, warning, and note messages that can be written to the SAS log during the execution of the DS2 program.

arguments.name: MSGORDER=
arguments.description: specifies whether DS2 writes error, warning, and note messages to the SAS log as they are produced or after the DS2 program completes.

arguments.name: REPORTLINE=
arguments.description: specifies whether log line numbers for the next program block are reported in DS2 program execution messages. The log line numbers are included in error, warning, and note messages and indicate the location of the DS2 statement that was being executed when the message was generated. Line numbers that are reported for stored packages and threads are the line numbers that are offset from the start of the package or thread block rather than SAS log line numbers.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: generates line numbers for DS2 program execution messages.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: suppresses generation of the log line numbers.

arguments.name: SAS
arguments.description: specifies that nonexistent values in fixed character columns and DOUBLE columns are processed as SAS missing values.

arguments.name: SCOND
arguments.description: specifies the level of messages that is displayed in the SAS log for the DS2 variable declaration strict mode, which requires that every variable must be declared in the DS2 program. For more information about the DS2 variable declaration strict mode, see .

arguments.name: TRACEVARIABLES
arguments.description: enables tracing of variable value changes during DS2 program execution.

arguments.name: TYPEWARN
arguments.description: prints a warning to the SAS log when an implicit type conversion occurs.

statements.name: ENDDATA
statements.description: Marks the end of a DATA statement.

statements.name: ENDPACKAGE
statements.description: Marks the end of a PACKAGE statement.

statements.name: ENDTHREAD
statements.description: Marks the end of a THREAD statement.

statements.name: FORWARD
statements.description: Indicates that the method definition follows the method expression.

arguments.name: method
arguments.description: specifies the name of the method to be defined.

statements.name: GOTO
statements.description: Transfers execution immediately to a labeled statement.

arguments.name: label
arguments.description: specifies a statement label that identifies the GOTO destination.

statements.name: IF
statements.description: Continues processing only those rows that meet the condition.

arguments.name: expression
arguments.description: is any valid expression that evaluates to true or false.

statements.name: IF-THEN/ELSE
statements.description: Executes a statement for rows that meet specific conditions.

arguments.name: expression
arguments.description: is any valid expression that evaluates to true or false and is a required argument.

arguments.name: statement
arguments.description: can be any executable statement or DO group.

statements.name: KEEP
statements.description: Includes columns in output tables.

arguments.name: column-list
arguments.description: specifies the names of one or more columns to write to the output table.

arguments.name: vararray
arguments.description: specifies the name of a variable array.

statements.name: Labels
statements.description: Identifies a statement that is referred to by another statement.

arguments.name: label
arguments.description: specifies any identifier, which is followed by a colon (:). You must specify the label argument.

arguments.name: statement
arguments.description: specifies any executable statement, including a null statement (;). You must specify the statement argument.

statements.name: LEAVE
statements.description: Stops processing the current DO loop and transfers execution to either the statement following the current DO statement, or a labeled DO statement that encloses the current DO statement.

arguments.name: identifier
arguments.description: label associated with the target DO statement.

statements.name: MERGE
statements.description: Joins rows from two or more tables into a single row.

arguments.name: table
arguments.description: specifies the name of the table. table can be one of these forms. • catalog.schema.table-name • schema.table-name • catalog.table-name • table-name • caslib.table-name

arguments.name: (table-options)
arguments.description: specifies optional arguments that the DS2 program applies when it writes rows to the output table.

arguments.name: /RETAIN
arguments.description: specifies that the final row of a data set in a particular BY group be used repeatedly until there are no more rows in any of the contributing data sets.

statements.name: METHOD
statements.description: Defines a block of code that can be called and executed multiple times.
statements.help:
[PRIVATE]
        METHOD 
        method ([[IN_OUT] <parameter> [,  ...
              [IN_OUT]<                   parameter>]] ) 
	
          [RETURNS data-type];
		
           ...method-body
           ...
        END ;
<parameter>::= 
	<data-type> variable
        
      
< data-type >::= 
	<exact-numeric-type> |           <approximate-numeric-type> | <binary-string-type> | <string-type>           
		| <date-type>
        
	<exact-numeric-type> ::= 
		               {INT  | BIGINT  | SMALLINT  |               TINYINT 
			 | DECIMAL 
            [(precision
                [,scale] )] | NUMERIC 
            [(precision
                [,scale])] }
        
        
	<approximate-numeric-type> ::=
		{ DOUBLE  |               DOUBLE PRECISION  | FLOAT  |               REAL  }
        
        
	<binary-string-type>::=
		BINARY (length) |               VARBINARY (length)
        
        
	<string-type>::= 
		NCHAR 
            [ ( character-length )               ]
          
		| NVARCHAR 
            [ ( character-length )               ]
          
		| CHAR 
            [ ( character-length )               ]
            [CHARACTER SET character-set-identifier]
          
		| VARCHAR 
            [ ( character-length )               ]
            [CHARACTER SET character-set-identifier]
        
        
	<date-type>::= 
		{ TIME  |               TIMESTAMP  } [ ( precision ) ] | DATE

arguments.name: method
arguments.description: specifies a name for the method. Method names have global scope.

arguments.name: method-body
arguments.description: comprises the variable declarations and executable DS2 code that runs when the method is called. All variables that are declared in the method body are local to the method.

arguments.name: END
arguments.description: marks the end of the method.

arguments.name: PRIVATE
arguments.description: specifies a method that can be accessed only from within the package.

arguments.name: IN_OUT
arguments.description: specifies that the argument is to be manipulated by reference, not by value. The IN_OUT parameter manipulates the argument rather than a copy of the argument.

arguments.name: parameter
arguments.description: specifies a parameter that is passed to the method. The type can be any valid character, numeric, or date type, or package. Parameters have scope that is local to the method and, by default, parameters are passed by value. A parameter is initialized to be a copy of the value of the argument that is specified for the parameter, unless it is specified with the IN_OUT parameter or is a package or an array. Package type variables and arrays are always passed by reference, even if the IN_OUT keyword is not specified.

arguments.name: INT
arguments.description: specifies an integer variable or array.

arguments.name: BIGINT
arguments.description: specifies an integer variable or array.

arguments.name: SMALLINT
arguments.description: specifies an integer variable or array.

arguments.name: TINYINT
arguments.description: specifies an integer variable or array.

arguments.name: DECIMAL[
arguments.description: specifies an exact numeric variable or array.

arguments.name: precision
arguments.description: specifies the maximum total number of decimal digits that can be stored, both to the left and to the right of the decimal point

arguments.name: scale
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of decimal digits that can be stored to the right of the decimal point

arguments.name: NUMERIC[
arguments.description: specifies an exact numeric variable or array.

arguments.name: precision
arguments.description: specifies the maximum total number of decimal digits that can be stored, both to the left and to the right of the decimal point

arguments.name: scale
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of decimal digits that can be stored to the right of the decimal point

arguments.name: DOUBLE
arguments.description: specifies a floating-point variable or array.

arguments.name: FLOAT
arguments.description: specifies a floating-point variable or array.

arguments.name: REAL
arguments.description: specifies a floating-point variable or array.

arguments.name: BINARY
arguments.description: specifies a binary variable or array.

arguments.name: VARBINARY
arguments.description: specifies a varying-length binary variable or array.

arguments.name: NCHAR
aliases: NATIONAL CHARACTER, NATIONAL CHAR for NCHAR
NATIONAL CHARACTER VARYING, NATIONAL CHAR VARYING for NVARCHAR
arguments.description: specifies a character variable or array.

arguments.name: NVARCHAR
aliases: NATIONAL CHARACTER, NATIONAL CHAR for NCHAR
NATIONAL CHARACTER VARYING, NATIONAL CHAR VARYING for NVARCHAR
arguments.description: specifies a character variable or array.

arguments.name: CHAR
aliases: NATIONAL CHARACTER, NATIONAL CHAR for NCHAR
NATIONAL CHARACTER VARYING, NATIONAL CHAR VARYING for NVARCHAR
arguments.description: specifies a character variable or array.

arguments.name: VARCHAR
aliases: NATIONAL CHARACTER, NATIONAL CHAR for NCHAR
NATIONAL CHARACTER VARYING, NATIONAL CHAR VARYING for NVARCHAR
arguments.description: specifies a character variable or array.

arguments.name: character-length
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of characters that the string can hold for NCHAR, NVARCHAR, CHAR, and VARCHAR data types.

arguments.name: CHARACTER
arguments.description: specifies character set encoding information for CHAR and VARCHAR data types.

arguments.name: TIME
arguments.description: specifies a time variable or array.

arguments.name: TIMESTAMP
arguments.description: specifies both a date and time variable or array.

arguments.name: precision
arguments.description: specifies the precision for a TIME or TIMESTAMP data type.

arguments.name: DATE
arguments.description: specifies a date variable or array.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: specifies the scalar variable or array name. You can specify one or more variables or arrays. However, variable can only be of the type specified in data-type. You can mix scalar and array variables of the same type.

arguments.name: RETURNS
arguments.description: specifies the data type of the value that the method returns. The type can be any valid character, numeric, or date type.

statements.name: Null
statements.description: Creates an empty statement.

statements.name: OUTPUT
statements.description: Writes the current row to a table.

arguments.name: table
arguments.description: specifies the name of the table to which to write rows. table can be one of these forms. • catalog.schema.table-name • schema.table-name • catalog.table-name • table-name • caslib.table-name

arguments.name: _ROWSET_
arguments.description: specifies that the OUTPUT statement should not write rows to a table, but it should instead return table rows to the client application.

arguments.name: _NULL_
arguments.description: specifies that the OUTPUT statement should not write rows to either a table or the client application.

statements.name: PACKAGE
statements.description: Creates a DS2 package.

arguments.name: catalog
arguments.description: is an implementation of the ANSI SQL standard for an SQL catalog, which is a data container object that groups logically related schemas. The catalog is the first-level (top) grouping mechanism in a data organization hierarchy that is used along with a schema to provide a means of qualifying names.

arguments.name: schema
arguments.description: is an implementation of the ANSI SQL standard for an SQL schema, which is a data container object that groups files such as tables and views and other objects supported by a data source such as stored procedures. The schema provides a grouping object that is used along with a catalog to provide a means of qualifying names.

arguments.name: package
arguments.description: is the name of the package.

arguments.name: package-body
arguments.description: contains the declarations and methods in the package.

arguments.name: fcmp-package-name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the FCMP package.

arguments.name: 'library-name'
arguments.description: specifies the name of the library where the FCMP function resides.

arguments.name: /ENCRYPT=
arguments.description: specifies the encryption algorithm. SAS specifies the SAS Proprietary algorithm. AES specifies the Advanced Encryption Standard algorithm.

arguments.name: /table-options
arguments.description: specifies optional arguments that the DS2 program applies when it creates a package. For more information about table options, see .

statements.name: PUT
statements.description: Prints the values of program variables, arrays, and constants to the SAS log.
statements.help:
PUT   < put-list > [ ... <put-list> ] ;  
	<put-list>::=  
		_ALL_ 
		| 'character-string' 
 
		| ['character-string']<eq-expression> [=] [[:]format[-L | -C | -R]]  
 
	<eq-expression>::=  
		identifier  
 
		| array-reference 
 
		| this-expression
		| package-attribute 
	<package-attribute>::=
		package-variable. package-attribute
		| package-variable ...[. package-variableN]. package-attribute

arguments.name: _ALL_
arguments.description: prints the values of all variables, which includes predefined variables, to the SAS log.

arguments.name: 'character-string'
arguments.description: specifies a string of text that is written to the SAS log.

arguments.name: identifier
arguments.description: names a variable whose value is written to the SAS log.

arguments.name: array-reference
arguments.description: specifies an array element. The subscript can be any SAS expression that resolves to an integer value when the PUT statement executes. Use the array subscript asterisk (*) to print all elements of the array.

arguments.name: this-expression
arguments.description: specifies a THIS expression.

arguments.name: package-attribute
arguments.description: specifies an attribute of a package that is referenced by a package-variable using a dot operator.

arguments.name: package-variable
arguments.description: specifies an instance of a package. The name of the package instance must be followed by a dot operator and a package-attribute.
(dot operator) invokes a call to access the right-hand operand from the left-hand operand.
If an equal sign is added after a variable or array element, then the output is preceded by the variable or array element name and an equal sign.
enables you to specify a format that the PUT statement uses to print the variable value. All leading and trailing blanks are deleted, and each value is followed by a single blank.

arguments.name: format
arguments.description: specifies a format to use when the data value is written to the SAS log. If you use a colon modifier (:) with the format name, all leading and trailing blanks are deleted and each value is followed by a single blank. To override the default alignment, you can add an alignment specification to a format:

statements.name: RENAME
statements.description: Specifies new names for columns in output tables.

arguments.name: old-name
arguments.description: specifies the name of a column as it appears in the input table, or in the current DS2 program for newly created columns.

arguments.name: new-name
arguments.description: specifies the name to use in the output table.

statements.name: RETAIN
statements.description: Specifies that all columns or all columns in the column list have their values retained between executions of the RUN method.
statements.help:
Form 1: 
RETAIN ;
Form 2: 
RETAIN  column-list;
Form 3: 
RETAIN  column-list < constant-value >;
Form 4: 
RETAIN  column-list ( < constant-value > …  < constant-value > );< constant-value >::=  
	bit_constant  
 
	| hex_constant 
 
	| floating_constant 
 
	| decimal_constant 
 
	| sas_missing_value 
 
	| integer_constant  
 
	| string_constant 
 
	| null  
 
	| DATE  character_constant 
 
	| TIME  character_constant 
 
	| TIMESTAMP  character_constant 
Form 5: 
RETAIN  vararray;

arguments.name: column-list
arguments.description: specifies column names whose values you want retained.

arguments.name: vararray
arguments.description: specifies the name of a variable array.

statements.name: RETURN
statements.description: Returns execution from a method to the method caller.

arguments.name: expression
arguments.description: specifies any valid expression that returns a single value. The expression's type is evaluated, and if necessary, converted to the type specified in the METHOD statement's RETURNS clause. The value of expression is then passed back to the caller of the method.

statements.name: SELECT
statements.description: Executes one of several statements or groups of statements.

arguments.name: select-expression
arguments.description: specifies an expression that evaluates to a single value of any type other than VARBINARY.

arguments.name: end-label
arguments.description: The END statement closes the SELECT statement. The optional end-label argument specifies an identifier. This label, created by using the Labels statement, must match the label immediately preceding the SELECT statement, or an error will occur.

arguments.name: when-expression
arguments.description: specifies any expression.

arguments.name: statement-list
arguments.description: can be any executable statement or statements.

statements.name: SET
statements.description: Reads rows from one or more tables.

arguments.name: table
arguments.description: specifies the name of an input table. table can be one of these forms. • catalog.schema.table-name • schema.table-name • catalog.table-name • table-name • caslib.table-name

arguments.name: {sql-text}
arguments.description: is any valid FedSQL code that resolves to a set of table rows.

arguments.name: INDSNAME=
arguments.description: creates and names a variable that stores the name of the table from which the current row is read. The stored name can be a table name or a physical name. The physical name is the name by which the operating environment recognizes the file.

arguments.name: column
arguments.description: names each column by which the table is sorted.

arguments.name: table-options
arguments.description: specifies optional arguments that the DS2 program applies when it writes rows to the output table. For more information about table options, see .

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: specifies that the tables are sorted in descending order by the column that is specified. DESCENDING means largest to smallest for numeric columns, or reverse alphabetical for character columns.

statements.name: SET FROM
statements.description: Runs a DS2 program as one or more threads.

arguments.name: catalog
arguments.description: is an implementation of the ANSI SQL standard for an SQL catalog, which is a data container object that groups logically related schemas. The catalog is the first-level (top) grouping mechanism in a data organization hierarchy that is used along with a schema to provide a means of qualifying names.

arguments.name: schema
arguments.description: is an implementation of the ANSI SQL standard for an SQL schema, which is a data container object that groups files such as tables and views and other objects supported by a data source such as stored procedures. The schema provides a grouping object that is used along with a catalog to provide a means of qualifying names.

arguments.name: thread
arguments.description: is the name of the thread.

arguments.name: THREADS=
arguments.description: specifies the number of threads that are run for thread.

statements.name: STOP
statements.description: Stops execution of the current DS2 program.

statements.name: Sum
statements.description: Adds or subtracts the result of an expression to an accumulator variable.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: specifies the name of the accumulator variable, which contains a numeric value.

arguments.name: expression
arguments.description: is any valid DS2 expression.

statements.name: THREAD
statements.description: Creates a DS2 program thread.

arguments.name: catalog
arguments.description: is an implementation of the ANSI SQL standard for an SQL catalog, which is a data container object that groups logically related schemas. The catalog is the first-level (top) grouping mechanism in a data organization hierarchy that is used along with a schema to provide a means of qualifying names.

arguments.name: schema
arguments.description: is an implementation of the ANSI SQL standard for an SQL schema, which is a data container object that groups files such as tables and views and other objects supported by a data source such as stored procedures. The schema provides a grouping object that is used along with a catalog to provide a means of qualifying names.

arguments.name: thread
arguments.description: is the name of the thread.

arguments.name: thread-body
arguments.description: contains the declarations and methods in the thread.

arguments.name: data-type
arguments.description: is an optional data type declaration. For more information, see .

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: names an optional variable that identifies the parameter.

arguments.name: /ENCRYPT=
arguments.description: specifies the encryption algorithm. SAS specifies the SAS Proprietary algorithm. AES specifies the Advanced Encryption Standard algorithm.

arguments.name: /table-options
arguments.description: specifies optional arguments that the DS2 program applies when it creates a thread. For more information about table options, see .

statements.name: VARARRAY
statements.description: Declares one or more DS2 variable arrays.
statements.help:
VARARRAY  <data-type> array-name <array-declaration> [<variable-list>] [<having-clause>];
< data-type >::= 
	<exact-numeric-type> | <approximate-numeric-type> | <binary-string-type> | <string-type> 
		| <date-type>  
	<exact-numeric-type> ::=  
		 {INT  | BIGINT  | SMALLINT  | TINYINT 
			 | DECIMAL  [(precision [,scale] )] | NUMERIC   [(precision [,scale])] }          
	<approximate-numeric-type> ::=
		{ DOUBLE  | DOUBLE PRECISION  | FLOAT  | REAL  }
	<binary-string-type>::=
		BINARY (length) | VARBINARY (length)
	<string-type>::=  
		NCHAR  [ ( character-length ) ]   
		| NVARCHAR  [ ( character-length ) ]   
		| CHAR  [ ( character-length ) ]  [CHARACTER SET  character-set-identifier ] 
 
		| VARCHAR  [ ( character-length ) ]  [CHARACTER SET  character-set-identifier ]  
 
	<date-type>::=  
		{ TIME  | TIMESTAMP  }  [ ( precision ) ] | DATE  
   
<array-declaration::=\[array-bound>[,  ...<array-bound>]\
	
	<array-bound>::= {[dim-lower:]dim-upper} | {[dim-lower:] {DIM(a[, n]) | *} }
<variable-list>::=  
	name-varlist | 
		| numbered-range-varlist
		|  name-range-list
		| name-prefix-list
		| type-varlist
		| special-name-list
<having-clause>::=  
	HAVING  <having-option> [… <having-option> ]  
		<having-option>::=  
			LABEL  'string' | n'string'  
			| FORMAT  format 
 
			| INFORMAT  format

arguments.name: INT
arguments.description: specifies an integer array.

arguments.name: BIGINT
arguments.description: specifies an integer array.

arguments.name: SMALLINT
arguments.description: specifies an integer array.

arguments.name: TINYINT
arguments.description: specifies an integer array.

arguments.name: DECIMAL[
arguments.description: specifies an exact numeric variable or array.

arguments.name: precision
arguments.description: specifies the maximum total number of decimal digits that can be stored, both to the left and to the right of the decimal point

arguments.name: scale
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of decimal digits that can be stored to the right of the decimal point

arguments.name: NUMERIC[
arguments.description: specifies an exact numeric variable or array.

arguments.name: precision
arguments.description: specifies the maximum total number of decimal digits that can be stored, both to the left and to the right of the decimal point

arguments.name: scale
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of decimal digits that can be stored to the right of the decimal point

arguments.name: DOUBLE
arguments.description: specifies a floating-point array.

arguments.name: FLOAT
arguments.description: specifies a floating-point array.

arguments.name: REAL
arguments.description: specifies a floating-point array.

arguments.name: BINARY
arguments.description: specifies a binary variable or array.

arguments.name: VARBINARY
arguments.description: specifies a fixed-length or varying-length binary array.

arguments.name: BINARY
arguments.description: specifies a fixed-length or varying-length binary array.

arguments.name: NCHAR
aliases: NATIONAL CHARACTER, NATIONAL CHAR for NCHAR
NATIONAL CHARACTER VARYING, NATIONAL CHAR VARYING for NVARCHAR
arguments.description: specifies a character array.

arguments.name: NVARCHAR
aliases: NATIONAL CHARACTER, NATIONAL CHAR for NCHAR
NATIONAL CHARACTER VARYING, NATIONAL CHAR VARYING for NVARCHAR
arguments.description: specifies a character array.

arguments.name: CHAR
aliases: NATIONAL CHARACTER, NATIONAL CHAR for NCHAR
NATIONAL CHARACTER VARYING, NATIONAL CHAR VARYING for NVARCHAR
arguments.description: specifies a character array.

arguments.name: VARCHAR
aliases: NATIONAL CHARACTER, NATIONAL CHAR for NCHAR
NATIONAL CHARACTER VARYING, NATIONAL CHAR VARYING for NVARCHAR
arguments.description: specifies a character array.

arguments.name: TIME
arguments.description: specifies a time array.

arguments.name: TIMESTAMP
arguments.description: specifies both a date and time array.

arguments.name: DIM
arguments.description: specifies that the size of the upper bounds of the array is determined by the number of elements in a dimension of a previously declared array by using a DIM function call.

arguments.name: a
arguments.description: specifies the name of a previously declared array.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the dimension, in a multidimensional array, for which you want to know the number of elements.
specifies a one-dimensional array in which the lower bound is 1 and the upper bound is the number of variables in the variable list.

arguments.name: character-length
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of characters that the string can hold for NCHAR, NVARCHAR, CHAR, and VARCHAR data types.

arguments.name: CHARACTER
arguments.description: specifies character set encoding information for CHAR and VARCHAR data types.

arguments.name: precision
arguments.description: specifies the precision for a TIME or TIMESTAMP data type.

arguments.name: DATE
arguments.description: specifies a date array.

arguments.name: and
arguments.description: specifies a positive or negative integer used to define the number and size of the array boundary.

arguments.name: <variable-list>
arguments.description: specifies the name of the variable(s) that is to be referenced by the elements of the array.

arguments.name: LABEL
arguments.description: assigns a descriptive label to the variable array. The label can be a CHAR literal (string) or NCHAR literal (nstring).

arguments.name: 'string'
arguments.description: assigns a descriptive label to the variable array. The label can be a CHAR literal (string) or NCHAR literal (nstring).

arguments.name: n''
arguments.description: assigns a descriptive label to the variable array. The label can be a CHAR literal (string) or NCHAR literal (nstring).

arguments.name: FORMAT
arguments.description: Associates any valid DS2 format with the variable or array.

arguments.name: INFORMAT
arguments.description: Associates any valid SAS informat with the variable or array.

statements.name: VARLIST
statements.description: Creates a named variable list.

arguments.name: list-name
arguments.description: specifies the name of the variable list.

arguments.name: [variable-list]
arguments.description: specifies the variables that are to be referenced by the list.
